Spondyloarthritis (SpA), including:

  • Ankylosing spondylitis (AS)
  • Reactive arthritis (ReA)
  • Arthritis-related inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD), Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis
  • Psoriatic arthritis (PsA)
  • Undifferentiated SpA (uSpA)
  • Juvenile-onset AS (JoAS)

Note: The terms "spondyloarthropathies" and "spondyloarthritis" are currently used indistinctly as a generic designation for any of the diseases that make up the group of SpA. This guideline preferentially uses the term "spondyloarthritis" because it better reflects the spinal and peripheral inflammatory nature of this disease group, and because it is the term most widely used in the specialty literature at this time.

• To provide explicit recommendations easily understood by users with the defined intention of influencing clinical practice
  • To reduce the variability in the management of spondyloarthritis (SpA), improving the quality of care by offering physicians who treat these patients practical recommendations adapted to their setting and based on the best, most up-to-date available evidence on the comprehensive management of SpA

Adults with spondyloarthritis (SpA) or suspected spondyloarthritis

Note: This guideline will not refer to SpA in children.

Diagnosis

  1. Early diagnosis and referral to rheumatologist
  2. Use of classification criteria appropriate for illness
  3. Assessment of patient
    • Medical history
    • Physical examination, including musculoskeletal
    • Laboratory tests (e.g., complete blood count, chemistry panel including liver profile, kidney function, calcium, acute phase reactants, urinalysis with sediment, rheumatoid factor [RF], anti-nuclear antibodies [ANA], and HLA-B27)
    • Radiographic study
  4. Evaluation during SpA follow-up
    • Global assessment of disease activity and patient assessment
    • Evaluation of physical function, structural damage, quality of life
    • Monitor complications (e.g., cardiac, pulmonary, renal, neurological)

Treatment/Management

  1. Early control of pain and inflammation
  2. Pharmacological
    • Analgesics
    • Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
    • Glucocorticoids
    • Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs)
    • Bisphosphonates
    • Thalidomide
    • Anti-TNF-α agents
  3. Non-pharmacological
    • Patient education
    • Lifestyle modifications
    • Rehabilitation
    • Exercise, according to disease stage
    • Physical measures (e.g., transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation, thermotherapy)
    • Manual therapies (e.g., massage, manipulations)
    • Balneotherapy
    • Occupational therapy
    • Orthopedic devices
  4. Local infiltration with glucocorticoids (intra-articular and peri-articular)
  5. Use of radiosynovectomy or chemical synovectomy
  6. Surgical treatment
  7. Management of extra-articular manifestations
    • Uveitis
    • Psoriasis
    • Intestinal bowel disease (IBD)

Field.Name: Description of Methods Used to Collect/Select the Evidence

FieldValue.Value:
The systematic reviews were carried out by members of the Spanish Society of Rheumatology (SER) Working Group on Evidence-Based Rheumatology. The reviewers conducted the systematic reviews of the questions agreed by the experts, according to the usual methodology of the group (developed in each review).

A documentalist (MPR) and a coordinator (JAML) reviewed all the search strategies so that the terms used for the selection of the population, intervention, and outcomes would be homogeneous among reviews, and provided the documents selected for the review. The literature review was carried out in 2008-2009 in the following databases:

  • MEDLINE (1950 to December 2009)
  • EMBASE (1974 to December 2009)
  • Cochrane Library (1993 to December 2009)
  • Abstracts of scientific meetings (American College of Rheumatology [ACR], EULAR) 2007-2009

A search by drug group was performed. Each of these searches includes common terms referring to the disease and the types of study. The search by drug groups will be specified in each systematic review cited in the text of Espoguia.

The reviews conducted are shown in Table 1 in the original guideline document.
5,696 titles were reviewed, and 124 articles were included in the reviews of one or more of the Key Questions.

Field.Name: Description of Methods Used to Formulate the Recommendations

FieldValue.Value:
Methodology

The methodology used to produce Espoguia is appropriate for the development of recommendations, and includes nominal groups of experts, Delphi surveys, and systematic review of the literature. The guideline was developed taking into consideration at all times the Appraisal of Guidelines for Research and Evaluation (AGREE) instrument for the evaluation of clinical practice guidelines, as a guide for the quality of Espoguia itself.

The panelist tasks were:

  1. To define the guideline contents and scope
  2. To develop the recommendations
  3. To develop the definitions
  4. To review and contribute to the synthesis of the evidence
  5. To write about unanticipated aspects that might emerge in developing the guideline (GPC)

Nominal Group to Establish the Scope, Definitions, and Tasks

Once the panelists were selected and had agreed to participate, a nominal group meeting was convened. In this meeting the GPC methodology was presented, including a theoretical introduction on the difference between recommendations, consensus statements and GPC, and the AGREE instrument. Panelists were also asked to come to the meeting prepared to establish the objective, users, organization, and needs for the literature review. To establish each of these aspects a secret vote was taken during the meeting, and agreement of over 60% was accepted as consensus.

At the first meeting all panelists received an editorial guideline as well as a document containing an update of all existing systematic reviews, GPCs, and consensus statements in the field of spondyloarthritis (SpA) management and treatment:

  • Recommendations for the treatment of ankylosing spondylitis (AS), both from the Assessment of SpondyloArthritis International Society (ASAS)/European League Against Rheumatism (EULAR) and from 3E Initiatives in Rheumatology
  • Clinical guidelines and consensus statements on anti-tumor necrosis factor alpha (anti-TNF-α) therapy in AS and psoriatic arthritis (PsA)
  • Recommendations for the treatment of SpA
  • Cochrane reviews of SpA

Preparation of the First Draft of Espoguia

The panelists began to write their corresponding chapters immediately after the nominal group meeting. A coordinator and two collaborators were assigned for each chapter.

Panelists were asked to write their recommendations so as to provide practical, specific advice on the subject treated. They were specifically asked to make their recommendations based on the risk/benefit balance for the patient, and not to take costs into account in their considerations. That is, the recommendation should be made thinking always of what would be most appropriate for the patient, consistent with the objective of improving the quality of care.

Development of the Recommendations

At the same time as the systematic reviews were being conducted, the expert panel was asked to make recommendations for their corresponding chapter.

These recommendations were compiled in a working document, and the panelists were asked to give their opinion or to clarify specific aspects of the recommendation.

Once the reviews were completed, they were sent to the expert panel for their assessment and for the initial evaluation of the level of evidence supporting their recommendations.

Final Meeting and Establishment of the Strength of the Recommendations

Both the experts and the reviewers were convened to discuss and come to agreement on the results of the reviews and the associated recommendations.

The levels of evidence of the Oxford Centre for Evidence-Based Medicine were used to rank the level of evidence and strength of the recommendations.

Another objective of this meeting was to quantify the level of agreement among the experts about each recommendation, as well as the consensus among them. These measures were determined using the Delphi method based on anonymous online surveys.

FieldValue.Value: On completion of the clinical practice guideline, it was sent for evaluation to external reviewers: a rheumatologist expert in this clinical area (JLFS) and a methodologist expert in developing clinical practice guidelines (MGM).

Definitions for the levels of evidence (1-5) and the grades of recommendations (A-D) are provided in Table 2 of the original guideline document.

Diagnosis

Suspected Spondyloarthritis

Recommendation 1. Inflammatory back pain and oligoperipheral arthritis, especially of the lower limbs, should be considered key data for suspected spondyloarthritis (SpA) [5, D].

Recommendation 2. Inflammatory back pain should be defined as back pain meeting ≥4 of the following criteria: 1) appearance before age 40, 2) insidious onset, 3) improvement with exercise, 4) no improvement with rest, 5) nocturnal pain [2b, B].

Early Diagnosis of SpA

Recommendation 3. Early diagnosis of patients with SpA should be considered a priority in rheumatology care [5, D].

The Detection of SpA in Primary Care

Recommendation 4. Activities/strategies/plans should be created and implemented to promote knowledge of SpA and cooperation between primary care physicians and rheumatologists in order to establish appropriate referral criteria for these patients [5, D].

Referral Criteria

Recommendation 5. Referral to the rheumatologist as quickly as possible is recommended for patients under age 45 with a) inflammatory back pain, b) asymmetric arthritis with preferential involvement of the lower limbs, enthesitis, dactylitis, or c) rachialgia or arthralgias + 1 of: psoriasis; inflammatory bowel disease (IBD); anterior uveitis; family history of SpA, psoriasis, IBD or anterior uveitis; radiographic sacroiliitis; or human leukocyte antigen (HLA)-B27+ [5, D]. (See Table 4, "Criteria for Referral from Primary Care to the Rheumatologist," in the original guideline document.)

Utility of Clinical, Laboratory, and Imaging Data for Early Diagnosis of SpA

Recommendation 6. The use of computerized tomography for the early diagnosis of SpA is not recommended [2b, B].

Recommendation 7. In cases of diagnostic uncertainty in patients strongly suspected of having SpA (including plain radiography without suggestive changes, HLA-B27 and other clinical parameters), an ultrasound study by experts can be recommended to assess both the number and degree of involvement of the entheses [2b, B].

Recommendation 8. Bone scintigraphy for the early diagnosis of SpA is not recommended [2a, B].

Recommendation 9. In cases of diagnostic uncertainty in patients strongly suspected of having SpA (including plain radiography without suggestive changes, HLA-B27 and other clinical parameters), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the sacroiliac joints can be recommended [2b, B].

Recommendation 10. Only acute inflammatory changes (edema/osteitis) that are clearly evident on MRI of the sacroiliac joints should be considered for the diagnosis of SpA [2b, B].

Diagnostic Criteria in SpA

Modified New York Criteria for the Diagnosis of Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS)

Recommendation 11. Despite its limitations for early diagnosis, the modified New York criteria are recommended for the diagnosis of AS [2b, B].

See Table 6 in the original guideline for the modified New York criteria.

Amor and European Study Group (ESSG) for the Diagnosis of SpA

Recommendation 12. Neither the European Study Group for Spondyloarthropathies (ESSG) nor the Amor criteria are recommended for the classification of SpA [2b, B].

Ankylosing Spondylitis Assessment Study (ASAS) Group Diagnostic Criteria for Axial SpA

Recommendation 13. The ASAS group criteria are recommended for the diagnosis of axial SpA [2b, B].

See Table 9 in the original guideline document for the classification criteria of the ASAS group.

Diagnostic Criteria for Reactive Arthritis (ReA)

Recommendation 14. The Berlin 1999 criteria are recommended for the diagnosis of ReA [2b, B].

See Table 14 in the original guideline document for the 1999 Berlin criteria.

Diagnostic Criteria for Psoriatic Arthritis (PsA)

Recommendation 15. The rheumatologist's clinical judgment or the Classification Criteria for Psoriatic Arthritis (CASPAR) criteria should be followed for the diagnosis of PsA (if it is predominantly peripheral) and the criteria of the Group for Research and Assessment of Psoriasis and Psoriatic Arthritis (GRAPPA) group for the diagnosis of axial involvement [5, D].

See Tables 12 and 13 in the original guideline document for the CASPAR and GRAPPA criteria.

Evaluation

General Considerations

Recommendation 16. Patients with SpA should be evaluated indefinitely, except for certain cases such as some ReA patients who appear to have complete disease remission [5, D].

Recommendation 17. All evaluations of patients with SpA should include a minimum set of parameters (which may vary depending on the type of SpA) that permit assessment of inflammatory activity, function, structural damage, and treatment response and toxicity; other disease domains can optionally be included in the patient assessment [5, D].

Recommendation 18. The use of specific forms, preferably in electronic format, is recommended, as they facilitate systematic collection of data on patients with SpA [5, D].

First Assessment of the Patient with SpA or Suspected SpA

Recommendation 19. The first assessment of a patient with SpA or suspected SpA should include: medical history, physical examination, laboratory tests (at a minimum: complete blood count, chemistry panel, erythrocyte sedimentation rate [ESR], C-reactive protein [CRP], immunology), radiological study, assessment of prognosis and treatment (if prescribed) [5, D].

Medical History

Recommendation 20. The medical history of patients with SpA should include: family and personal history, sociodemographic data, previous history of the disease, current symptoms and treatments (previous and concomitant) [5, D]. (See original guideline document for more information on the variables to be collected in SPA medical history.)

Physical Examination

Recommendation 21. Besides the general examination of organs and systems, the physical examination in SpA patients should include a detailed assessment of the musculoskeletal system [5, D].

See Table 18 in the original guideline document for a summary of elements to include in the physical exam for SpA.

Examination of the Axial Skeleton

Recommendation 22. Examination of the cervical, dorsal and lumbar spine is recommended in all SpA patients to detect the presence of pain on palpation/manipulation, paravertebral muscle tone, swelling or deformities. Correct assessment of spinal mobility is especially important [5, D].

See Table 20 in the original guideline document for a description of examination of the axial skeleton and hips, together with specific tests.

Joint Examination

Recommendation 23. Examination of 44 to 78 joints is recommended, depending on the type of SpA, noting the presence of swelling on palpation, periarticular muscle tone, mobility, gait, and presence of deformities [5, D].

See Table 21 in the original guideline document for maneuvers in examination of the sacroiliac joints and hips.

Assessment of Entheses

Recommendation 24. The entheses should be assessed in all patients with SpA, using one of the available instruments [5, D].

See Table 22 in the original guideline document for location of the entheses to be evaluated with the different assessment instruments.

Assessment of Dactylitis

Recommendation 25. All patients with SpA should be evaluated for dactylitis, noting whether it is present or absent, and if it is acute or chronic [5, D].

Laboratory Tests

Recommendation 26. At the first assessment of patients with SpA, the following laboratory tests are recommended: a complete blood count, basic chemistry panel including liver profile (glutamate oxaloacetate transaminase [GOT], glutamic-pyruvic transaminase [GPT], gamma glutamyl transferase [GGT], phosphatase, alkaline, albumin), kidney function (creatinine), calcium, acute phase reactants (ESR, CRP), urinalysis with sediment, rheumatoid factor (RF), antinuclear antibody (ANA), and HLA-B27 [5, D].

Radiographic Study and Other Imaging Techniques

Recommendation 27. The initial baseline radiological examination should include plain radiographs (X-rays), the localization of which will vary according to the type of SpA. They include: posterior-anterior (PA) projection of the pelvis (sacroiliac joints and hips), PA and lateral projection of the three segments of the vertebral column, the chest, and peripheral joints [5, D].

Evaluation of Prognosis

Recommendation 28. Prognosis should be evaluated at each visit of the patient with SpA (in the first visit, with the data available at that time), which should include sociodemographic, socioeconomic, and work-related factors, genetic markers (if accessible), disease-dependent factors, treatment and psychological factors [5, D].

See Table 24 in the original guideline document for prognostic factors in spondyloarthritis.

Evaluation During SpA Follow-up

Recommendation 29. Patients with SpA should be evaluated at least once a year; this interval can be modified according to the type and severity of SpA, patient characteristics, and type and strategy of treatment [5, D].

Recommendation 30. Follow-up of the SpA patient should be systematized and should include collection of socioeconomic, clinical, laboratory, and radiological data, as well as treatment response/toxicity [5, D].

See Table 25 in the original guideline document for the minimum set of variables to be collected during follow-up of spondyloarthritis.

Measurement Instruments for Assessment of Each Domain

Evaluation of Inflammatory Activity

Recommendation 31. To evaluate inflammatory activity, the following is recommended: assessment of back pain (overall and nocturnal), patient global assessment (PtGA), physician global assessment (PhGA), swollen joint count, and enthesopathies (including dactylitis), and acute phase reactants [5, D].

Evaluation of Spinal Pain

Recommendation 32. Both overall and nocturnal spinal pain should be evaluated separately, using a 10 cm horizontal scale divided into 10 equal 1-cm segments, with numerical descriptors from 0 to 10 and labels at each end indicating "No pain" (0) and "Worst pain" (10) [5, D].

See Figure 5 in the original guideline document for recommended scale for pain assessment.

Patient Global Disease Assessment (Numerical Rating Scale)

Recommendation 33. The patient global assessment of disease activity should be measured using a 10 cm horizontal scale divided into 10 equal 1-cm segments, with numerical descriptors from 0 to 10 and labels at each end indicating "No activity" (0) and "Highest activity" (10) [5, D].

See Figure 6 in the original guideline document for recommended scale for patient global disease assessment.

Physician Global Disease Assessment

Recommendation 34. The physician global assessment of disease activity should be measured using a 10 cm horizontal scale divided into 10 equal 1-cm segments, with numerical descriptors from 0 to 10 and labels at each end indicating "No activity" (0) and "Highest activity" (10) [5, D].

See Figure 7 in the original guideline document for recommended scale for physician global disease assessment.

Patient Global Disease Assessment (Bath Ankylosing Spondylitis Disease Activity Index [BASDAI])

Recommendation 35. The patient global disease assessment should be measured using the BASDAI questionnaire [5, D].

See Figure 8 in the original guideline document for BASDAI using a numerical scale.

Evaluation of Physical Function

Bath Ankylosing Spondylitis Functional Index (BASFI)

Recommendation 36. The BASFI is recommended as an instrument to evaluate physical function [5, D].

See Figure 9 in the original guideline document for BASFI using a numerical scale.

Other Evaluation Instruments

Evaluation of Quality of Life

Recommendation 37. For those interested in evaluating the quality of life of patients with SpA, the use of either validated generic questionnaires like the SF (short form)-12 or specific questionnaires like the Ankylosing Spondylitis Quality of Life (ASQoL) or Psoriatic Arthritis Quality of Life (PsAQoL) are recommended [5, D]. (See the original guideline document for more information, including questionnaires on ASQoL and PsAQoL.)

Comorbidity in SpA

Recommendation 38. The rheumatologist should monitor and control SpA-associated comorbidity, in collaboration with the primary care physician and other specialists if needed, and should seek the active participation of patients themselves [5, D].

Complications of SpA

Recommendation 39. Extra-articular manifestations (like uveitis, IBD, or psoriasis) should be ruled out in all patients with SpA [5, D]. Informing the patient in this respect can be very helpful for early diagnosis [5, D].

Cardiac Complications

Recommendation 40. A systematic search for possible cardiac complications by complementary tests is not recommended in the absence of clinical manifestations or other factors indicating such complications [5, D].

Pulmonary Complications

Recommendation 41. A systematic search for possible pulmonary complications by complementary tests is not recommended in the absence of clinical manifestations or other factors indicating such complications [5, D].

Renal Complications

Recommendation 42. In patients with SpA, routine kidney function tests, urinalysis, and monitoring of blood pressure are recommended in accordance with the characteristics of each case (inflammatory activity, treatment, age, associated comorbidities, etc.) [5, D].

Neurological Complications

Recommendation 43. Careful assessment of any neurological sign is recommended in patients with SpA [5, D].

Comorbidity Not Directly Related to SpA

Osteoporosis

Recommendation 44. Physicians should be aware of the possibility that SpA patients may develop osteoporosis. The need for additional tests to diagnose this condition should be assessed depending on the risk factors and clinical characteristics of each case [5, D]. Interpretation of the lumbar bone mineral densitometry may be difficult if calcifications are present in the spinal entheses; hip densitometry should be assessed if this is the case [5, D].

Cardiovascular Comorbidity

Recommendation 45. In patients with SpA, inflammatory disease activity should be reduced to the maximum extent possible, and the traditional disease factors should be adequately controlled [5, D].

Pharmacological Treatment

General Considerations

Recommendation 46. SpA treatment should be adjusted to the clinical manifestations of the disease, severity of the symptoms, other clinical findings, and prognostic factors, as well as general patient characteristics (age, sex, comorbidity, etc.), preferences and expectations [5, D].

Recommendation 47. Optimal management of SpA patients requires a combination of pharmacological and non-pharmacological treatments which should be started as early as possible [5, D].

Objective of Treatment

Recommendation 48. The goal of SpA treatment is disease remission or, failing that, the maximum possible reduction of inflammation in order to achieve significant improvement of signs and symptoms (joint inflammation, pain, axial and peripheral stiffness, etc.), preserve functional capacity, maintain good quality of life, and control structural damage [5, D].

Drugs (Efficacy and Safety)

Analgesics

Recommendation 49. Analgesics like paracetamol or opiates can be offered to patients with SpA whose pain is not controlled with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), or when NSAIDs are contraindicated or poorly tolerated [5, D].

Nonsteroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drugs

Recommendation 50. The NSAIDs are recommended (unless contraindicated) as first-line treatment for the control of pain and stiffness and to improve function in patients with SpA [1b, A]. Once the therapeutic goal is achieved, the minimum effective dose should be maintained [5, D]. Before considering an NSAID to be ineffective, it should have been administered for at least 2-4 weeks at the maximum recommended or tolerated doses [4, C].

Glucocorticoids

Recommendation 51. Local glucocorticoids (GC) infiltrations are recommended in SpA patients refractory to NSAIDs [1c, A]. The use of systemic GCs is recommended only in exceptional situations of major inflammation [2b, B].

Disease-Modifying Antirheumatic Drugs (DMARDs)

Recommendation 52. In SpA patients who are refractory to NSAIDs, the use of DMARDs should be evaluated [1a, A].

Sulfasalazine

Recommendation 53. Routine use of sulfasalazine (SSZ) is not recommended for treatment of axial symptoms in SpA [1a, A], but it is indicated in cases of peripheral involvement [1a, A] and for other extra-articular manifestations like uveitis [2c, B] and IBD [1a, A].

Methotrexate

Recommendation 54. The use of methotrexate (MTX) should be evaluated individually in patients with AS, undifferentiated SpA (uSpA) or reactive arthritis (ReA) (especially peripheral forms and enthesitis) who are refractory to all available treatments with proven efficacy [5, D]. MTX should be assessed for routine use in PsA [2a, B] and in extra-articular manifestations like uveitis [2c, B] and IBD [1a, A].

Leflunomide

Recommendation 55. The use of leflunomide (LEF) should be evaluated individually in patients with AS, uSpA and ReA (especially in peripheral forms and enthesitis), and extra-articular manifestations refractory to all available treatments with proven efficacy [5, D]. LEF should be assessed for routine use in PsA for peripheral arthritis and dactylitis [1b, A], and enthesitis [5, D].

Cyclosporin A

Recommendation 56. The use of cyclosporin A (CsA) should be evaluated individually in patients with AS, uSpA and ReA (especially in peripheral forms and enthesitis), refractory to all available treatments with proven effectiveness [5, D]. Its use should be assessed in extraarticular manifestations [2b, B] and in PsA for peripheral arthritis and dactylitis [2b, B], and enthesitis [5, D].

Other DMARDs

Recommendation 57. SpA patients who are clinically active and in whom other treatments have failed or are not possible should be evaluated individually for possible use of azathioprine (AZA), gold salts, cyclophosphamide, or d-penicillamine provided that the potential benefit is considered to outweigh the possible adverse events [5, D].

Other Pharmacological Treatments (Efficacy and Safety)

Bisphosphonates

Recommendation 58. Pamidronate may be offered in selected cases to SpA patients who are refractory to conventional treatments and in whom initiation of anti-TNF therapy is contraindicated [5, D].

Thalidomide

Recommendation 59. SpA patients with particularly severe axial involvement and who are refractory to all therapies with proven efficacy should be evaluated individually for possible use of thalidomide, with special attention to its toxicity profile [5, D].

Treatment Changes and Evaluation

Recommendation 60. Whenever the therapeutic goal is not attained, the patient's treatment should be reevaluated [5, D].

Recommendation 61. The recommended variables for evaluation of treatment response in SpA are the BASDAI, PtGA, nocturnal spinal pain, arthritis/enthesitis, the Disease Activity Score-28 (DAS-28), and acute phase reactants (APRs) [5, D].

Patients without Previous Treatment

Recommendation 62. In SpA, it is recommended that pharmacological treatment be evaluated at 3-4 months [5, D].

Recommendation 63. In patients with predominantly axial SpA, anti-TNF-α agents should be used if, after 3 months of NSAID treatment, the BASDAI remains ≥4, together with at least one of the following criteria: a) PtGA ≥4; b) nocturnal pain ≥4; c) elevated APR. In any case, the opinion of a rheumatologist or physician expert in SpA is essential [5, D].

Recommendation 64. For peripheral forms of SpA, the anti-TNF-α are indicated if, despite treatment with at least two NSAIDs, SSZ (AS and PsA), or other DMARDs (PsA) and local treatments, arthritis or enthesitis persist for more than 3-4 months, in addition to PtGA ≥4 and/or elevated ESR/CRP and, for pure polyarticular arthritis, if the patient's DAS-28 is ≥3.2 [5, D].

Recommendation 65. In SpA, certain conditions such as monoarthritis, enthesitis, or some extra-articular manifestations refractory to conventional treatment which have a pronounced functional or other type of impact on the patient, must be considered as treatment failure [5, D].

Patients with Previous Treatment

Recommendation 66. In SpA patients who are considered not to have been treated correctly, treatment should be restarted or completed correctly before an anti-TNF-α is indicated [5, D].

Recommendation 67. In patients with SpA who responded to a DMARD that was subsequently withdrawn, in case of a new flare-up, the same DMARD should be prescribed before indicating an anti-TNF-α [5, D].

Evaluation of Response to TNFα Antagonist Agents

Recommendation 68. A patient with SpA and axial involvement will be considered to respond to anti-TNF-α if, after 3-4 months of treatment, disease remission is achieved or there is a 50% relative decrease on the BASDAI (or an absolute reduction of 2 points with respect to previous values) in at least one of the following: PtGA, nocturnal axial pain (if both were >4 before treatment), or reduction in ESR and/or CRP (if they were previously elevated) [5, D].

Recommendation 69. SpA patients with axial involvement who have not responded to one anti-TNF-α can switch to a second anti-TNF-α [5, D].

Recommendation 70. In SpA patients with axial involvement, if the response achieved with the second anti-TNF-α is <50% but >20% on the BASDAI and the PtGA, since the most effective therapeutic options currently available will have been used, treatment with the biological agent that the clinician considers of choice should be maintained unless one of the nonbiological treatments previously used would have been more effective, in which case consideration should be given to reinstating that treatment [5, D].

Recommendation 71. In SpA patients with axial involvement, if the response achieved with the second anti-TNF-α is <20% on the BASDAI and PtGA, the anti-TNF-α should be withdrawn if deemed advisable by the physician [5, D].

Recommendation 72. SpA patients with peripheral polyarticular involvement who are taking an anti-TNF-α agent should achieve clinical remission (DAS28 <2.6) or at least reduce inflammatory activity to DAS28 <3.2. When this is not achieved, a DAS reduction of 1.2 (from the previous level) would be accepted as sufficient to maintain treatment with the anti-TNF-α that the clinician considers to be of choice, unless one of the non-biological treatments previously used would have been more effective, in which case its reinstatement should be considered [5, D].

Treatment of Pain

Recommendation 73. Control of pain is essential from the time of symptom onset in SpA, with NSAIDs being the treatment of choice [1b, A]. Analgesics can be used if the response to NSAIDs is insufficient or if there is intolerance or contraindication to their use [5, D].

Recommendation 74. In SpA, paracetamol at a dosage of 3-4 g/day is considered the analgesic of choice [5, D].

SpA Treatment in Special Situations

Elderly Patients

Recommendation 75. When making treatment decisions for elderly patients with SpA, changes in pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics typical of increased age should be kept clearly in mind [5, D].

Recommendation 76. Strict monitoring of kidney and liver function is recommended in elderly patients with SpA, as well as adjustment of the dosage of drugs eliminated by these routes [5, D].

Recommendation 77. In elderly patients with SpA and immunosuppressive treatments, the possible appearance of adverse events and interactions with their usual drugs should be strictly monitored [5, D].

Recommendation 78. In elderly SpA patients treated with biological therapies, strict monitoring of possible related adverse events is recommended, with special attention to infections, neoplasia, and heart failure [4, C]. It is also recommended to follow the same indications for vaccination as for the young adult population [4, C].

Pregnancy, Breastfeeding, and Fertility

Pregnancy and Breastfeeding

Recommendation 79. Patients of childbearing age (both men and women) should be informed of the possible effects of SpA with regard to fertility, pregnancy and breastfeeding, and in particular of the effect of their drug treatments in these areas [5, D].

Recommendation 80. Controlled use of NSAIDs is recommended in SpA patients during pregnancy in cases where this is justified, and they should be discontinued 6-8 weeks before delivery; during the lactation period, they should be taken while breastfeeding [4, C].

Recommendation 81. In SpA patients, it is recommended that GCs (preferably prednisone, [methyl]prednisolone, cortisone, or hydrocortisone) be used during pregnancy only in justified cases and under close control. High doses should be avoided (especially in the first trimester), and a stress dose should be used during delivery [4, C]. If high doses of GCs are required during lactation, it is suggested that women should breastfeed 4 hours after the last dose [4, C].

Recommendation 82. Thalidomide is contraindicated in SpA patients during pregnancy [2b, B]. and its use during breastfeeding is not recommended [5, D].

Recommendation 83. The use of pamidronate in SpA patients should be evaluated individually during pregnancy and lactation, reserving it for those cases in which the benefit of the therapy clearly outweighs the possible toxic effects [4, C].

Recommendation 84. The use of antimalarials (preferably hydroxychloroquine, at doses routinely used in rheumatology) should be evaluated individually in SpA patients during pregnancy and lactation, reserving it for those cases in which the benefit of therapy clearly outweighs its possible toxic effects [3b, B].

Recommendation 85. MTX is contraindicated in SpA patients during pregnancy and lactation [2b, B]. Contraceptive measures should be used during treatment in both men and women, and treatment should be discontinued 3-4 months before conception [4, C].

Recommendation 86. The use of CsA should be evaluated individually in SpA patients during pregnancy, reserving it for those cases in which the benefit of therapy clearly outweighs the possible toxic effects [2b, B]. Its use during breastfeeding is not recommended [4, C].

Recommendation 87. The use of mycophenolate mofetil should be evaluated individually in SpA patients during pregnancy, reserving it for those cases in which the benefit of therapy clearly outweighs the possible toxic effects [2b, B]. Treatment should be discontinued 6 weeks before conception [5, D]. Its use during breastfeeding is not recommended [4, C].

Recommendation 88. The use of SSZ (at doses of ≤2 g/day) in SpA patients during pregnancy should be closely controlled and administered only in cases where it is justified [2b, B]. It should be discontinued during one complete menstrual cycle before conception in women (if not considered necessary during the pregnancy) and 2-3 months before conception in men [5, D].

Recommendation 89. LEF is contraindicated in SpA patients during pregnancy and lactation. Contraceptive measures should be used (in both men and women) before beginning treatment. In case of pregnancy and/or if a male wishes to have children, it should be discontinued immediately, and treatment should be started with cholestyramine at 8 g 3 times a day for 11 days, until reaching LEF plasma levels of <0.02 mg/l in two tests conducted 2 weeks apart; couples should then wait 3 months before conception [5, D].

Recommendation 90. Gold salts are not recommended in SpA patients during pregnancy and lactation [4, C].

Recommendation 91. D-penicillamine is contraindicated in SpA patients during pregnancy and lactation [4, C].

Recommendation 92. The use of AZA should be evaluated individually in SpA patients during pregnancy, reserving it for those cases in which the benefit of the therapy clearly outweighs the possible toxic effects [4, C]. Its use during lactation is not recommended [4, C].

Recommendation 93. The use of cyclophosphamide should be evaluated individually in SpA patients during pregnancy; it should be avoided in the first trimester and reserved for those cases in which the benefit of the therapy clearly outweighs the possible toxic effects [2b, B]. Its use during lactation is not recommended [4, C].

Recommendation 94. The use of biological therapy should be evaluated individually in SpA patients during pregnancy, reserving it for those cases in which the benefit of the therapy clearly outweighs the possible toxic effects [2a, B]. Its use during lactation is not recommended [2b, B].

Secondary Amyloidosis

Recommendation 95. In patients with SpA and secondary amyloidosis, strict control of the underlying disease is recommended, as well as periodic monitoring of the levels of serum amyloid A protein [5, D].

Recommendation 96. In patients with long-term SpA, deterioration of renal function and/or development of proteinuria not explained by any other cause should lead the clinician to suspect a possible case of secondary amyloidosis [2b, B].

Enthesitis

Recommendation 97. The recommended treatments of choice in SpA are NSAIDs [2b, B], physical therapy, and ortheses [3b, B]. Local infiltrations of GCs may be considered in cases that are refractory/intolerant to NSAIDs [4, C]. If all these fail, the use of anti-TNF may be considered [1b, B].

Undifferentiated Spondyloarthritis

Recommendation 98. Early control of pain and inflammation is essential in patients with uSpA. It should be treated with drugs of proven efficacy in the established forms of SpA, and response to treatment should be monitored individually [5, D].

Reactive Arthritis

Diagnosis

Recommendation 99. Patients with suspected ReA and urethritis or cervicitis should be tested for Chlamydia trachomatis in the urine, or in urethral or cervical exudate, and patients with diarrhea should be tested for enterobacterias in feces and serum [5, D].

Treatment

Recommendation 100. NSAIDs are recommended in the acute phases of ReA [2b, B], and use of GCs (oral or infiltrations) should be considered in cases of severe inflammation [5, D]. Patients who are refractory or intolerant to these treatments, or who have chronic involvement or erosive disease, should begin DMARD treatment [2b, B]. If symptoms persist, consider treatment with an anti-TNF-α agent [4, C].

Antibiotic Therapy

Recommendation 101. Antibiotic treatment in ReA is indicated in patients with acute genitourinary infection from Chlamydia, or with a previously documented untreated infection, but it is not recommended in patients with established ReA [1c, A].

Other Treatments

Education and Lifestyle Modification

Education

Recommendation 102. Patients with SpA should be informed about all aspects of their disease, including its evolution and all aspects of their treatment [4, C].

Lifestyle Changes

Recommendation 103. Patients with SpA should be advised to stop smoking [4, C].

Rehabilitation

Exercise Programs

Recommendation 104. Exercise programs should be an important part of SpA treatment since they improve physical function, flexibility, and overall feelings of wellbeing [1a, A].

Recommendations According to Disease Stage

Recommendation 105. A program of aerobic exercise is recommended in early stages of disease [2b, B]. When the patient has partial limitation of mobility, stretching exercises should be added [1b, A]. In cases that progress to ankylosis, aerobic and strengthening exercises can be combined [4, C].

Strategies to Improve Adherence

Recommendation 106. For maximum effectiveness, strategies should be used to improve adherence (education, initial supervision, patient associations, etc.) [4, C].

Physical Measures

Recommendation 107. Application of physical agents (transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation [TENS], thermotherapy, etc.) to symptomatic regions may improve pain and the feeling of stiffness in some patients [2b, B].

Manual Therapies

Recommendation 108. Spinal manipulations are absolutely contraindicated in patients with advanced AS who have active inflammation and/or stiff or inflexible spines and/or fragile or unstable spines, especially if they are middle aged or elderly [4, C].

Balneotherapy

Recommendation 109. Balneotherapy can be recommended in SpA patients without active disease when other, more accessible therapies have proven ineffective [2b, B].

Occupational Therapy

Recommendation 110. Occupational therapy and prescription of assistive devices may be indicated in advanced cases when impairment begins to cause some type of functional limitation in carrying out the activities of daily living [1b, A]. (See the original guideline document for recommendations and assistive devices for the activities of daily living.)

Local and Intra-Articular Treatment

Local Infiltrations with Glucocorticoids

Recommendation 111. The use of local GC infiltrations (intra- or peri-articular) should be considered in SpA patients who are refractory to conventional treatments and/or who have major inflammation of the entheses and bursae [4, C], peripheral joints [5, D], and sacroiliac joints [1c, A]; accessibility and possible side effects should always be evaluated.

Recommendation 112. Infiltration with slow-release GCs is recommended [5, D].

Radioisotopic Synovectomy

Recommendation 113. The use of radiosynovectomy should be individually assessed in SpA patients with chronic synovitis producing pain and/or disability, and who are refractory to or cannot tolerate conventional treatments (including GC infiltration) [2b, B].

Recommendation 114. GCs should be administered in combination with synovectomy [4, C].

Recommendation 115. Synovectomy is not recommended in AS patients who have not yet reached skeletal maturity [5, D].

Surgical Treatment in SpA

Surgery of the Spine

Recommendation 116. In AS patients, spinal surgery should be resorted to only in highly selected patients who have considerable pain or disability and are refractory to medical treatment [2c, B].

Hip Surgery

Recommendation 117. Hip arthroplasty is recommended in SpA patients who have considerable pain or disability and evidence of structural damage, and who are refractory to medical treatment [2b, B].

Radiation

Recommendation 118. Radiation is not recommended in the treatment of SpA [2b, B].

Extra-Articular Manifestations

Uveitis

General Considerations

Recommendation 119. Uveitis should be considered a medical emergency, and early, aggressive treatment should be started to minimize the risk of developing ocular complications [5, D].

Clinical Picture and Diagnosis

Recommendation 120. Interdisciplinary collaboration between ophthalmologists and rheumatologists is recommended, preferably jointly in uveitis units for the diagnosis, treatment, and follow-up of SpA patients with uveitis [5, D].

See Table 56 in the original guideline document for the most frequent diagnoses (including ophthalmological syndromes and screening and/or complementary tests to be considered depending on type of uveitis).

Treatment

Recommendation 121. SpA patients who have more than three acute anterior uveitis (AAU) flares per year should be treated with SSZ or MTX [2b, B]. Initial treatment with biological therapies is not recommended [5, D].

Psoriasis

Diagnosis

Recommendation 122. Cutaneous psoriasis should be diagnosed by visualization of the lesions, preferably by an expert in dermatology, and histological diagnosis should be reserved for exceptional cases [5, D].

Evaluation of Psoriasis

Recommendation 123. In clinical practice, evaluation of psoriasis patients should be guided by the "rule of tens," considering psoriasis to be severe when either the Psoriasis Area Severity Index (PASI), body surface area (BSA) or Dermatology Life Quality Index (DLQI) score is higher than 10 [5, D].

Treatment

Recommendation 124. All psoriasis patients should maintain good skin hygiene [1b, A].

Intestinal Bowel Disease

Diagnosis

Recommendation 125. If there is the slightest suspicion of intestinal involvement, patients should be referred to a digestive system specialist for further study [5, D].

Ankylosing Spondylitis

Disease Course and Prognosis

Recommendation 126. AS patients should be diagnosed and started on appropriate treatment as early as possible [1, A].

Evaluation

First Evaluation of Patient with AS/Suspected AS

Recommendation 127. The first evaluation of a patient with AS or suspected AS should include: a medical history, physical examination, laboratory tests (at a minimum: complete blood count, chemistry panel, ESR, CRP, HLA-B27), x-ray examination (sacroiliac joints, hips and spine), and assessment of prognosis [5, D].

See Table 60 in the original guideline for the first assessment of patient with ankylosing spondylitis.

Recommendation 128. Morning back stiffness in AS patients should be evaluated in terms of its duration in minutes [5, D].

Recommendation 129. A 44-swollen joint count is recommended in AS patients [5, D].

Recommendation 130. Given the prognostic and functional importance of the hip in AS, a complete clinical evaluation of this joint should be conducted routinely [5, D].

Recommendation 131. The BASDAI should be administered to AS patients for assessment of both disease activity and response to treatment [5, D].

Recommendation 132. To evaluate function in AS patients, the BASFI is recommended as the first option; alternatively, the Dougados Functional Index (DFI) can be used [5, D].

Recommendation 133. Spinal mobility should be evaluated in AS patients (as part of the evaluation of function) using the modified Schöber test, finger-floor distance, lateral lumbar flexion, chest expansion, occiput-wall and cervical rotation [5, D].

Recommendation 134. The entheses should be evaluated for tenderness to palpation in AS patients, following a validated enthesis index (preferably the Maastricht Ankylosing Spondylitis Enthesis Score [MASES] index) [5, D].

Recommendation 135. Structural damage should be assessed in AS by plain anteroposterior (AP) radiograph of the pelvis and AP and lateral x-ray of the three segments of the spinal column, following a graduated scale based on the New York criteria (sacroiliac joints) and the Modified Stoke Ankylosing Spondylitis Score (mSASS) (spine). Additional radiographs should be considered if other joints are affected [5, D].

Recommendation 136. Both ESR and CRP should be evaluated in AS [5, D].

Recommendation 137. HLA-B27 and other biomarkers should be requested in AS patients, depending on the diagnostic uncertainty [5, D].

Recommendation 138. The prognosis in AS patients should be evaluated considering factors like male sex, early age at onset, the presence of peripheral arthritis, smoking, low educational level or low socioeconomic status, regular practice of an activity requiring intense physical effort, or lack of physical activity [5, D].

Evaluation During AS Follow-up

Recommendation 139. Systematic follow-up of AS patients is recommended. This should include collection of socio-occupational, clinical, laboratory, and imaging data, prognoses, and treatment response/toxicity. Their frequency will depend on the type of variable and characteristics of the patient and treatment [5, D].

See Table 61 for follow-up of patients with ankylosing spondylitis.

Frequency of Monitoring in AS

Recommendation 140. After AS is diagnosed, patients should be monitored frequently (from 2 to 4 weeks to 1.5 to 3 months) to check the evolution of disease activity and treatment response/toxicity. Subsequently, when patients are in remission, or have a low level of activity or a good therapeutic response, they should be monitored every 6 to 12 months, except for patients needing pharmacological monitoring of DMARD or anti-TNF-α treatment, who should be checked every 2 to 4 months [5, D].

Recommendation 141. Cases of acute back pain, peripheral arthritis or extra-articular manifestations should be evaluated as soon as possible; and in the case of some manifestations like uveitis, emergency evaluation is recommended [5, D].

Evaluation of Response to Treatment

Recommendation 142. The following definitions are recommended when evaluating response to treatment [5, D].

Disease remission: Absence of symptoms, signs, and any other data indicative of AS activity.

Disease activity: The presence at 3-4 months, in axial forms, of a BASDAI ≥4 and at least one of: PtGA >4, nocturnal back pain >4, increase in acute phase reactants. In peripheral forms: persistence of arthritis and/or enthesitis in ≥1 site and at least one of: PtGA >4, increase in acute phase reactants.

Least possible clinical activity: BASDAI ≤2, PtGA <2; alternatively, BASDAI, PtGA and nocturnal back pain <4.

Treatment Response Measures/Criteria

Recommendation 143. The variables recommended for treatment response in AS are the BASDAI, PtGA, nocturnal back pain, arthritis/enthesitis, and acute phase reactants [5, D].

Changes in Treatment

Recommendation 144. Whenever the therapeutic goal is not reached in AS, a treatment decision must be made [5, D].

Recommendation 145. NSAIDs should be continued at the minimum effective dose in AS patients who reach the therapeutic goal [5, D].

Recommendation 146. Axial AS should be considered as not responding to treatment if after 3-4 months of treatment at full/maximum tolerated doses of at least 2 NSAIDs, the BASDAI is ≥4 and (one of the following): PtGA ≥4, nocturnal pain ≥4 and/or the acute phase reactants are elevated [5, D].

Recommendation 147. Peripheral AS should be considered as not responding to treatment if after 3-4 months of treatment at full/maximum tolerated doses of (NSAIDs and/or SSZ, local GCs and chemical synovectomy), the arthritis/enthesitis persists and the ESR ≥4 and/or the acute phase reactants are elevated [5, D].

Recommendation 148. Response to an anti-TNF-α agent in AS patients should be evaluated every 3-4 months, taking into account the BASDAI, PtGA, nocturnal back pain, and the acute phase reactants [5, D].

Treatment of AS

General Considerations

Recommendation 149. The choice of treatment in AS should be based on disease and patient characteristics [5, D].

See Table 67 in the original guideline document for factors on which treatment should be based in patients with AS.

Pharmacological Treatment of AS

NSAID and Other Analgesics

Recommendation 150. NSAIDs are the treatment of choice in AS patients [1b, A].

Recommendation 151. The Cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) inhibitors can be considered in AS patients who are NSAID refractory or intolerant, or in whom NSAIDs are contraindicated [1b, A].

Glucocorticoids (GCs)

Recommendation 152. Intra- or periarticular GC infiltration can be considered as adjunctive therapy in selected patients with AS and sacroiliitis [1c, A], persistent monoarthritis or oligoarthritis, or enthesitis [5, D], so long as the possible risk of adverse events, especially tendon rupture, is continually monitored. The use of systemic GCs is recommended only in exceptional situations of major inflammation [2b, B].

DMARDs and Other Drugs

Recommendation 153. SSZ is recommended in peripheral AS [1a, A] and in cases of uveitis [2c, B].

Recommendation 154. The use of MTX should be evaluated individually in AS patients who are refractory to all available treatments of proven efficacy (especially those with peripheral forms and enthesitis) [5, D], and patients with uveitis [2c, B].

Recommendation 155. The use of LEF should be evaluated individually in patients with peripheral AS who are refractory to all available treatments of proven efficacy [5, D].

Recommendation 156. The use of CsA, AZA, gold salts, cyclophosphamide and D-penicillamine should be evaluated individually in AS patients who are clinically active whenever other treatments are not possible or the remaining available therapies have failed and the potential benefit is considered to exceed the possible adverse events [5, D].

Recommendation 157. The use of thalidomide should be evaluated individually in patients with particularly severe axial AS refractory to all available therapies of proven efficacy, always keeping in mind its toxicity profile [5, D].

Recommendation 158. Pamidronate may be offered in selected cases to AS patients refractory to conventional treatments and in whom initiation of anti-TNF-α therapy is contraindicated [5, D].

Biological Therapy

Recommendation 159. When use of an anti-TNF-α is indicated in AS, the choice of agent is at the physician's discretion, and depends on the manifestations and circumstances particular to each patient [5, D].

Recommendation 160. The use of infliximab (IFX) is recommended in patients with axial AS who are refractory to NSAIDs and other symptomatic treatments (analgesics, local GC infiltrations), and in patients with peripheral AS who are refractory to NSAIDs, DMARDs, and symptomatic treatments (analgesics, local GC infiltrations, synoviorthesis) [1a, A].

Recommendation 161. Etanercept (ETN) is recommended in axial AS patients refractory to NSAIDs and other symptomatic treatments (analgesics, local GC infiltrations), and in peripheral AS patients refractory to NSAIDs, DMARDs and symptomatic treatments (analgesics, local GC infiltrations, synoviorthesis) [1a, A].

Recommendation 162. The use of adalimumab (ADA) is recommended in axial AS patients refractory to NSAIDs and other symptomatic treatments (analgesics, local GC infiltrations), and in peripheral AS patients refractory to NSAIDs, DMARDs and symptomatic treatments (analgesics, local GC infiltrations, synoviorthesis) [1a, A].

Radiation Synovectomy

Recommendation 163. Radioisotopic synovectomy should be considered in cases of AS with arthritis that is very symptomatic and/or produces major functional impairment, and which is refractory to conventional treatments including GC infiltration [5, D].

Non-Pharmacological Treatment

Education

Recommendation 164. Patients with AS should be informed about all aspects related to their disease, including its evolution and complete information on its treatment [4, C], and should be advised to stop smoking [4, C].

Rehabilitation

Recommendation 165. In AS patients, the exercise type, technique or program should be adjusted to the specific requirements of the patient's disease, characteristics, particular circumstances and preferences, as well as the available resources [5, D].

Exercise Programs

Recommendation 166. Physical exercise should be routinely indicated in AS patients [1b, A].

Recommendation 167. All available strategies should be used to increase the level of compliance with the exercise program, especially in the case of exercises done at home [4, C].

Recommendation 168. In the early phases a program of aerobic exercise is recommended. [2b, B] When the patient develops partial limitation of mobility, stretching exercises should be added [1b, A]. In cases that progress to ankylosis, aerobic and strengthening exercises can be combined [4, C].

Other Measures

Recommendation 169. Spinal manipulations are absolutely contraindicated in patients with advanced AS, especially if they are of middle or advanced age, who have active inflammation and/or spinal columns that are rigid or inflexible and/or fragile or unstable [4, C].

Recommendation 170. Occupational therapy and the prescription of assistive devices may be indicated in cases of advanced AS [1b, A]. (See Table 69 in the original guideline document for recommendations and assistive devices for the activities of daily living.)

Surgical Treatment

Recommendation 171. Surgical treatment should be indicated for AS patients with major pain and/or disability that is refractory to medical treatment [2b, B].

Psoriatic Arthritis

Evaluation

General Considerations

Recommendation 172. Beginning with the first visit, the patient with PsA should be evaluated, at a minimum, for disease activity, function, and structural damage, as well as treatment response and toxicity, and prognosis [5, D].

First Evaluation of the Patient with PsA or Suspected PsA

Recommendation 173. The first evaluation of a patient with PsA/suspected PsA should include: medical history, physical examination, laboratory tests (at a minimum: complete blood count, chemistry panel, ESR, CRP, RF), radiographic study (chest, sacroiliac joints, other affected joints) and assessment of prognosis [5, D]. (See Table 78 in the original guideline document for more information on the first evaluation of the patient with PsA.)

Recommendation 174. In evaluating the different domains of PsA it is important to take into account the contribution of both musculoskeletal and other manifestations of the disease, like skin involvement [5, D].

Recommendation 175. In patients with PsA, pain should be evaluated and the PtGA and PhGA should be obtained with reference to the past week (preferably using horizontal numerical scales from 0 to 10, or alternatively the visual analog scale [VAS] from 0 to 10 cm) [5, D].

Recommendation 176. Fatigue should be evaluated, however, no specific instrument is recommended for this purpose. A horizontal numerical scale (1-10) would be acceptable [5, D].

Recommendation 177. The evaluation of PsA patients should include a peripheral joint assessment (66 joints for swelling and 68 joints for tenderness) [5, D].

Recommendation 178. Axial involvement in PsA should be evaluated with the BASFI, modified Schöber test, lateral flexion of the lumbar spine, finger-floor distance, chest expansion, occiput-wall/tragus-wall distance, and cervical rotation [5, D].

Recommendation 179. No particular enthesitis index is recommended in PsA patients, but the MASES index appears to be preferable [5, D].

Recommendation 180. Patients with PsA should be evaluated routinely for dactylitis, indicating its presence/absence and whether it is acute or chronic [1b, A].

Recommendation 181. The quality of life of these patients should be evaluated using the SF-12 or SF-36 [1b, A].

Recommendation 182. The Health Assessment Questionnaire (HAQ) is recommended for the evaluation of function (disability) in PsA patients with peripheral joint involvement [1b, A].

Recommendation 183. No particular instrument is recommended for the assessment of skin and nail involvement in daily practice, but clinicians should note the presence or absence of onychopathy, and a dermatologist should be consulted in case of doubt [5, D].

Recommendation 184. In patients with suspected PsA, radiographs should be obtained of the affected skeletal regions as well as an AP radiograph of the pelvis to detect sacroiliitis [5, D].

Recommendation 185. No particular method for the assessment of structural damage is recommended; the Sharp-van der Heijde index modified for PsA is preferable for peripheral joint assessment, and the Modified Stoke Ankylosing Spondylitis Spinal Score (mSASSS) for axial involvement [5, D].

Recommendation 186. Both ESR and CRP should be evaluated in PsA [5, D].

Recommendation 187. PsA prognosis should be assessed taking into account factors such as sex, number of swollen joints, ESR, drug failure, and disease with joint damage, loss of function, or reduced quality of life [5, D].

Assessment During Follow-up of PsA

Recommendation 188. Systematic follow-up of PsA patients should include collection of socio-occupational, clinical, analytic, and radiological data, as well as treatment response/toxicity. The frequency of follow-up will depend on the type of variable and patient characteristics [5, D].

Frequency of Follow-up

Recommendation 189. Patients with PsA should be followed up at least once a year if they are controlled and do not require other pharmacological monitoring [5, D].

Recommendation 190. Patients with PsA who need to be evaluated for treatment effectiveness or therapeutic compliance, or whose drugs require specific monitoring, should be assessed every 2 weeks to 3-4 months [5, D].

Recommendation 191. Patients with PsA and severe exacerbation, unexpected adverse effects to treatment, fever, or rapid deterioration of their general condition should be evaluated in the shortest possible time, no later than one week [5, D].

Evaluation of Treatment Response

Recommendation 192. The definitions listed below are recommended [5, D].

Remission of disease is defined as the absence of signs, symptoms, and any other findings indicative of PsA activity.

Active disease is defined as:

  • In oligoarticular forms, if there is persistence of arthritis/enthesitis and PtGA >4 or acute phase reactants are elevated
  • In polyarticular forms, if DAS28 ≥2
  • In cases of axial involvement, if BASDAI >4 and at least one of: PtGA >4, nocturnal axial pain >4 or elevated acute phase reactants

Treatment Response Measures/Criteria

Recommendation 193. In assessing the response to treatment the use of a composite index is recommended, such as the DAS28 (preferable, and using a count of 66 swollen joints and 68 tender joints), the Psoriatic Arthritis Response Criteria (PsARC), or the American College of Rheumatology (ACR) response criteria modified for PsA [5, D]. (See Tables 81 and 82 in the original guideline document for more information on psoriatic arthritis response criteria.)

Recommendation 194. The recommended variables for treatment response in PsA are the DAS28, BASDAI, PtGA, nocturnal back pain, and the acute phase reactants [5, D].

Changes in Treatment

Recommendation 195. Whenever the therapeutic goal is not achieved in PsA, a treatment decision must be made [5, D].

Recommendation 196. PsA patients who reach the treatment goal should continue the prescribed treatment at the minimum effective dose [5, D]

Recommendation 197. Patients with peripheral PsA should be considered as not responding to treatment if arthritis/enthesitis persists after 3-4 months of treatment at full/maximum tolerated doses of (NSAIDs and DMARDs, local GCs and synovectomy), and PtGA ≥4 and/or acute phase reactants are elevated [5, D].

Recommendation 198. Patients with axial PsA should be considered as not responding to treatment if, after 3-4 months of treatment at full/maximum tolerated doses of at least two NSAIDs, the BASDAI is ≥4 and (one of the following): PtGA ≥4, nocturnal pain ≥4 and/or acute phase reactants are elevated [5, D].

Recommendation 199. The response to an anti-TNF-α agent should be evaluated in PsA every 3-4 months, taking into account the DAS28, BASDAI, PtGA, nocturnal back pain, and acute phase reactants [5, D].

Treatment

General Considerations

Recommendation 200. The choice of treatment in PsA should be based on disease and patient characteristics [5, D]. (See Table 83 in the original guideline document for the factors on which to base treatment in patients with PsA.)

Pharmacological Treatment of Psoriatic Arthritis

NSAIDs

Recommendation 201. The use of NSAIDs is recommended to control symptoms in patients with PsA and peripheral arthritis [1b, A], as well as for axial involvement [1b, A], enthesitis [4, D], and dactylitis [5, D].

GCs

Recommendation 202. In patients with PsA, the use of systemic GCs is recommended in very selected cases of severe joint involvement [5, D]. GC infiltrations are recommended in patients with monoarthritis, oligoarthritis, or polyarthritis with one or two especially symptomatic joints [5, D], and in enthesitis [5, D].

DMARDs

Recommendation 203. The use of SSZ in PsA is recommended for the treatment of arthritis [1a, A] and dactylitis [2a, B], but not for enthesitis [1a, A] or axial involvement [1c, A].

Recommendation 204. The use of MTX is recommended in PsA patients with peripheral arthritis [2a, B], refractory enthesitis [5, D] and dactylitis [5, D].

Recommendation 205. The use of LEF should be evaluated in PsA with peripheral arthritis and dactylitis [1b, A], and may be considered in cases of refractory enthesitis [5, D].

Recommendation 206. The use of CsA should be evaluated in PsA for the treatment of arthritis and dactylitis [2b, B], and may be considered in cases of refractory enthesitis [5, D].

Recommendation 207. The use of AZA, gold salts, D-penicillamine, and antimalarials should be evaluated in patients with clinically active PsA provided that other treatments have failed or are not possible, and the potential benefit is considered to outweigh the possible adverse effects [5, D].

Treatment with Anti-TNF-α Agents

Recommendation 208. When the use of an anti-TNF-α is indicated, the choice of agent will depend on the physician's judgment and on each patient's particular manifestations and circumstances [5, D].

Recommendation 209. The use of IFX is recommended in patients with peripheral PsA who are refractory to NSAIDs, DMARDs and symptomatic treatments (analgesics, local GC infiltrations, synoviorthesis), and in PsA patients with axial disease who are refractory to NSAIDs and other symptomatic treatments (analgesics, local GC infiltrations) [1a, A].

Recommendation 210. The use of ETN is recommended in patients with peripheral PsA who are refractory to NSAIDs, DMARDs and symptomatic treatments (analgesics, local GC infiltrations, synoviorthesis), and in PsA patients with axial disease who are refractory to NSAIDs and other symptomatic treatments (analgesics, local GC infiltrations) [1a, A].

Recommendation 211. The use of ADA is recommended in patients with peripheral PsA who are refractory to NSAIDs, DMARDs and symptomatic treatments (analgesics, local GC infiltrations, synoviorthesis), and in PsA patients with axial disease who are refractory to NSAIDs and other symptomatic treatments (analgesics, local GC infiltrations) [1a, A].

Other Pharmacological Treatments

Recommendation 212. Infiltration with slow release GCs is recommended in patients with PsA [4, C], taking care to avoid areas of psoriasis.

Recommendation 213. In patients who are refractory to conventional treatments including GC infiltration, radioisotope synovectomy should be evaluated (administered together with GCs) if the arthritis is highly symptomatic and/or causes major functional impairment [5, D].

Non-Pharmacological Treatment of PsA

Education

Recommendation 214. PsA patients should be informed about all aspects related to their disease, including its course and complete information about its treatment [4, C].

Rehabilitation

Recommendation 215. In PsA the type, technique, or program of exercise should be adjusted to the specific requirements of the patient's disease, characteristics, particular circumstances and preferences, as well as the available resources [5, D].

Recommendation 216. Routine physical exercise should be recommended for all PsA patients [5, D].

Recommendation 217. Patients with PsA should use all available strategies to increase the level of compliance with the exercise program, especially in the case of exercises done at home [5, D].

Surgical Treatment

Recommendation 218. Surgical treatment should be recommended in PsA patients with important pain and/or disability refractory to medical treatment [2b, B].

Patients and Nurses in SpA

Role of Patients and Patient Associations in SpA

General Considerations

Recommendation 219. The most active possible participation of the patient in all disease-related processes is recommended, including research [5, D].

Patient Associations

Recommendation 220. Patients should be given more information on all aspects related to their disease at the beginning of the disease process and throughout its entire course [5, D].

Recommendation 221. Knowledge, awareness, and dissemination of the work of patient associations should be increased, and explicit information should be provided to all patients on the possibilities offered by these associations [5, D].

The Role of Nurses in SpA

Recommendation 222. The rheumatological care of patients with SpA should include care provided by nursing staff [5, D].
